text.text: We're excited to be hosting you in the Wallet and ApplePay channel this week! You can find the full schedule of Q&As for Wallet and ApplePay by visiting the <https://apps.apple.com/us/app/apple-developer/id640199958 | Apple Developer app> and <https://developer.apple.com/events/ask-apple/questions-and-answers/ | website>.
If you haven’t already, please take a moment to familiarize yourself with <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=vpbyzfg4 | how Q&As will work>.

We want to make sure these spaces are helpful and welcoming for everyone — developers and Apple employees alike. Please review and follow the <https://developer.apple.com/events/policy/online-event-attendance-policy/ | attendance policy>.

messages.text: <@U03V30M0C1K> added a workflow to this channel: *Ask Apple - wallet-and-apple-pay*.

elements.text: added a workflow to this channel:
Ask Apple - wallet-and-apple-pay

messages.text: Welcome to the Wallet and Apple Pay Q&A! The team is really looking forward to answering your questions. Select the:heavy_plus_sign:icon from the lower left, and choose the _Ask A Question_ workflow. Type in your question and it will be delivered directly to us. While we’ll answer as many questions as we can (this is a broad topic!), all your submissions and feedback are super valuable. Thank you for joining us! :shopping_trolley: :credit_card:

elements.text: Welcome to the Wallet and Apple Pay Q&A! The team is really looking forward to answering your questions. Select the
icon from the lower left, and choose the
Ask A Question

workflow. Type in your question and it will be delivered directly to us. While we’ll answer as many questions as we can (this is a broad topic!), all your submissions and feedback are super valuable. Thank you for joining us!

messages.text:
<@U046G17N76V> asked
> Published reports indicate that CarPlay 2.0 will allow a user to pay for gasoline and start an Automated Fuel Dispenser (AFD).  How will that be accomplished in the absence of a near-field communication device or terminal, which only operates within 10 cm?  Is the communication through ApplePay’s payment processing system? Is there another communication device involved, which identifies the vehicle that is being refueled to and with an AFD, so as to minimize fraud? Will CarPlay 2.0 have its own modules for ensuring PCI DSS compliance?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Published reports indicate that CarPlay 2.0 will allow a user to pay for gasoline and start an Automated Fuel Dispenser (AFD).  How will that be accomplished in the absence of a near-field communication device or terminal, which only operates within 10 cm?  Is the communication through ApplePay\u2019s payment processing system? Is there another communication device involved, which identifies the vehicle that is being refueled to and with an AFD, so as to minimize fraud? Will CarPlay 2.0 have its own modules for ensuring PCI DSS compliance?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks for your question. The CarPlay Q&A is the best place to get details behind this capability.

elements.text: Thanks for your question. The CarPlay Q&A is the best place to get details behind this capability.

messages.text:
<@U04670E4SLU> asked
> Earlier I have came across a news where is Apple will releasing a capability to add IDCards like Driving License into wallet app in super secure manner like we do it with Credit Cards right now.
> 
> I wanted to know by when this can be available for most of the US states?
> 
> Also can you share some documentation which can help me understand third party integration.

elements.text: asked

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Arizona and Maryland residents can add their driver’s license to Wallet today! Other states will add support in the future, including Colorado, Connecticut, Georgia, Hawaii, Iowa, Kentucky, Mississippi, Ohio, Oklahoma and Utah, as well as the territory of Puerto Rico.

Starting in iOS 16, your app can request identity information from the user’s driver’s license. For more information check out this year’s Apple Pay & Wallet WWDC session: <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10041/>, You can also look at our developer documentation: <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/passkit/wallet/requesting_identity_data_from_a_wallet_pass>

attachments.fallback: Apple Developer: What’s new in Wallet and Apple Pay - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
attachments.title: What’s new in Wallet and Apple Pay - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
attachments.text: Discover the latest updates to Wallet & Apple Pay. We'll show you how to support Orders in Wallet for your apps and websites and securely...

elements.text:

Starting in iOS 16, your app can request identity information from the user’s driver’s license. For more information check out this year’s Apple Pay & Wallet WWDC session:
, You can also look at our developer documentation:

messages.text:
<@U046PVC75SR> asked
> What is the preferred way for developers to handle a .pkpasses bundle, both on web and within iOS? The pkpasses ingestion appears to be Safari specific, rather than Webkit/WKWebView, which means users on Chrome for iOS, Firefox, or custom in app browsers will not be able to download the archive to their wallet successfully.
> 
> Should developers be checking for a specific Safari User Agent in this scenario before offering a .pkpasses bundle?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the preferred way for developers to handle a .pkpasses bundle, both on web and within iOS? The pkpasses ingestion appears to be Safari specific, rather than Webkit\/WKWebView, which means users on Chrome for iOS, Firefox, or custom in app browsers will not be able to download the archive to their wallet successfully.\n\nShould developers be checking for a specific Safari User Agent in this scenario before offering a .pkpasses bundle?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Support for viewing and downloading pkpass files and bundles is implemented at the browser level, rather than within WebKit/WKWebView. Details can be found here: <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/walletpasses/distributing_and_updating_a_pass>. However, non-Safari browsers should simply download the pass for the end user to open. Please file a feedback report for a broader implementation and paste the number here so we can track it. Thanks!

elements.text: Support for viewing and downloading pkpass files and bundles is implemented at the browser level, rather than within WebKit/WKWebView. Details can be found here:

. However, non-Safari browsers should simply download the pass for the end user to open. Please file a feedback report for a broader implementation and paste the number here so we can track it. Thanks!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Adding Mobile Driver’s license to your Wallet is only available to some states in the US like Arizona and Maryland. Other states will add support in the future, including Colorado, Connecticut, Georgia, Hawaii, Iowa, Kentucky, Mississippi, Ohio, Oklahoma and Utah, as well as the territory of Puerto Rico.  And of course…a Feedback report for the desired support is always welcome.

Other states will add support in the future, including Colorado, Connecticut, Georgia, Hawaii, Iowa, Kentucky, Mississippi, Ohio, Oklahoma and Utah, as well as the territory of Puerto Rico.  And of course…a Feedback report for the desired support is always welcome.

messages.text: Welcome back to the Wallet and Apple Pay Q&A! Once again, we’re looking forward to answering your questions. To ask a question, select the:heavy_plus_sign:icon in the lower left and choose the _Ask A Question_ workflow. Type in your question and it will be delivered directly to us. We’ll answer as many questions as we can (lots of moving parts in this one!) but even if we can’t get to them all, please know that your questions and feedback are super valuable. Thank you for joining us! :shopping_trolley: :credit_card:

messages.text:
<@U046PVC75SR> asked
> The 10 pass limit of a .pkpasses archive is not documented anywhere, and was only confirmed to me as part of FB11304325, but this limit should be documented. It would also be useful for my app's use case to have this limit raised. My use case is that we allow customer to add all rail tickets at once for a specific journey,  which can include over ten separate tickets. Currently, we have to support a flow of if the user attempts to download our .pkpasses bundle from the web, we have to direct them to our app, which nullifies having Wallet support available on desktop browsers

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"The 10 pass limit of a .pkpasses archive is not documented anywhere, and was only confirmed to me as part of FB11304325, but this limit should be documented. It would also be useful for my app's use case to have this limit raised. My use case is that we allow customer to add all rail tickets at once for a specific journey,  which can include over ten separate tickets. Currently, we have to support a flow of if the user attempts to download our .pkpasses bundle from the web, we have to direct them to our app, which nullifies having Wallet support available on desktop browsers"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thank you for highlighting this and filing feedback, we'll review the documentation.

elements.text: Thank you for highlighting this and filing feedback, we'll review the documentation.

messages.text:
<@U046RFUBXJ5> asked
> I’d like to implement Apple Pay as a way for the customer to buy my Mac desktop application (outside of the Mac App Store), right within the app (without using the Safari browser). However my experience was disappointing. First, it’s turned out that Mac has its own wallet that is different from the iPhone wallet, i.e. you have to manually re-add cards you already have in your iPhone wallet to the Mac wallet. Second, the Mac wallet isn’t enabled by default, and in order to enable it, the user has to reboot in safe mode and turn on some obscure deeply buried setting. All in all it looks like too much trouble for 98% of the users. I have also tried to use WebKit component embedded into my app window in order to use Apple Pay via web, but the Apple Pay extension is blocked in component mode for security reasons. The end result is that Apple Pay only reasonably works in stand-alone web browser and only in Safari. Am I doing something wrong? Are there plans to improve support of Apple Pay on the Mac, addressing the above mentioned problems?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I\u2019d like to implement Apple Pay as a way for the customer to buy my Mac desktop application (outside of the Mac App Store), right within the app (without using the Safari browser). However my experience was disappointing. First, it\u2019s turned out that Mac has its own wallet that is different from the iPhone wallet, i.e. you have to manually re-add cards you already have in your iPhone wallet to the Mac wallet. Second, the Mac wallet isn\u2019t enabled by default, and in order to enable it, the user has to reboot in safe mode and turn on some obscure deeply buried setting. All in all it looks like too much trouble for 98% of the users. I have also tried to use WebKit component embedded into my app window in order to use Apple Pay via web, but the Apple Pay extension is blocked in component mode for security reasons. The end result is that Apple Pay only reasonably works in stand-alone web browser and only in Safari. Am I doing something wrong? Are there plans to improve support of Apple Pay on the Mac, addressing the above mentioned problems?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hi Oleg. Wallet & Apple Pay on macOS should be enabled by default for the vast majority of users, but can be disabled if certain security settings have been modified. And thank you for your feedback regarding the macOS Apple Pay experience.

elements.text: Hi Oleg. Wallet & Apple Pay on macOS should be enabled by default for the vast majority of users, but can be disabled if certain security settings have been modified. And thank you for your feedback regarding the macOS Apple Pay experience.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Allright, suppose I accidentally changed my Mac’s security settings and my wallet became disabled and I forgot about it. But still, I think most people are used to use Apple Pay via their phones. It looks like an unreasonable expectation that the customer must first add his cards to the Mac wallet in order to be able to pay on the Mac. Ideally, it should work like in Safari - once the user initiates a payment in the app, his phone shows up the confirmation screen and he confirms on the phone. That’s the experience that most people would expect, I guess. Can this be implemented in macOS, are there any plans for this?

messages.text:
<@U0474C3GHD3> asked
> My company provides SaS to over 1000 merchants. We provide around 40 different payment methods currently.  We are currently adding Apple Pay to that list.  We have already been approved by Apple to use the Mass Enablement API to register individual merchants to use ApplePay benefits.  However, we are not the credit card processor, we need to be able register merchants each with their own Payment Processing certificate.  Currently we are only able to encrypt payment data from all merchants to one payment processing certificate.  This will not work for us.  How can register each merchant to their own payment processing certificate?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"My company provides SaS to over 1000 merchants. We provide around 40 different payment methods currently.  We are currently adding Apple Pay to that list.  We have already been approved by Apple to use the Mass Enablement API to register individual merchants to use ApplePay benefits.  However, we are not the credit card processor, we need to be able register merchants each with their own Payment Processing certificate.  Currently we are only able to encrypt payment data from all merchants to one payment processing certificate.  This will not work for us.  How can register each merchant to their own payment processing certificate?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Typically when you register a merchant through the <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/applepaywebmerchantregistrationapi/registermerchantrequest|mass enablement API> you would provide your own merchant identifier in the *`encryptTo`* property, because you want to handle decryption on their behalf.

However, you can provide another merchant identifier here instead. This would allow your merchants to register with their own merchant identifiers and certificates.

This does require your merchants to register their own merchant identifiers on <http://developer.apple.com|developer.apple.com>, and provide those to you. Please do file a Feedback request if you think there are further improvements to the mass enablement API that would assist your use cases.

elements.text: Typically when you register a merchant through the
mass enablement API
you would provide your own merchant identifier in the
encryptTo

property, because you want to handle decryption on their behalf.

However, you can provide another merchant identifier here instead. This would allow your merchants to register with their own merchant identifiers and certificates.

This does require your merchants to register their own merchant identifiers on
developer.apple.com
, and provide those to you. Please do file a Feedback request if you think there are further improvements to the mass enablement API that would assist your use cases.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That means each merchant would have to pay for an Apple Dev account, but they are not developers.  It feels like there should be a better way.  Hasn't this issue come up before?  It seems like this would happen frequently.

elements.text: That means each merchant would have to pay for an Apple Dev account, but they are not developers.  It feels like there should be a better way.  Hasn't this issue come up before?  It seems like this would happen frequently.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Yes, a developer account would be required.

Another option is decrypting the payment information and passing it to the merchant, who can send unencrypted to their payment processor. Most payment processors are happy to receive unencrypted Apple Pay payment data.

elements.text:
Yes, a developer account would be required.

Another option is decrypting the payment information and passing it to the merchant, who can send unencrypted to their payment processor. Most payment processors are happy to receive unencrypted Apple Pay payment data.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: So we can send "Device Account IDs" to a payment processor and they should be able to handle that as well?  I mean as opposed to the actual credit card number.

elements.text: So we can send "Device Account IDs" to a payment processor and they should be able to handle that as well?  I mean as opposed to the actual credit card number.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes, that's correct.

elements.text: Yes, that's correct.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Great.  Thank you very much.  Loved the Q&A session.

elements.text: Great.  Thank you very much.  Loved the Q&A session.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It should be possible to create a .pkpass file in any programming language. We do not provide sample code in C# however we do have documentation here: <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/walletpasses/building_a_pass/>

elements.text: It should be possible to create a .pkpass file in any programming language. We do not provide sample code in C# however we do have documentation here:
